data.title: NBA Team Profiles: Charlotte Hornets
data.meta_description: The Charlotte Hornets have been doing okay this season. They are ranked 14th in the Eastern Conference but judging by the Charlotte Hornets odds, no one really thinks they can do better.
data.text:
LaMelo Ball – Guard

Baller in name, baller in nature. LaMelo has created 23.1 points per game and has an assist-per-game average of 8.0.

Ball was the third overall pick in 2020 and since entering the court in 2021, he has already become a team hero. He was the first Hornet to enter the All-Rookie First team in 16 years, and the first Rookie of the Year winner in 16 years.

Many fans suggest we are currently in the LaMelo Ball era of the Hornets.

We haven’t had such a boost since the 2014 Drafts. In that season the Hornets picked up Noah Vonleg, Nicolas Batum, Jeremy Lamb, and Jeremy Lin.

By the end of 2015, our stats had improved to 48 wins over 34 losses. This was the biggest win in Franchise history.

In 2016, we were points away from the playoffs, which shows just how intense that boost was.

LaMelo may bring us to the playoffs this year. But so far we might be repeating history.

James Bouknight – Guard

Bouknight has been on the team for 1 year and was picked 11th in the drafts. So far he hasn’t made a real impact having played for 6 minutes maximum in a game.

Every game that Bouknight has played, ended in a loss.

Terry Rozier – Guard

Rozier has also played in 100% losing games. Having been on the team for 7 years, there isn’t really an excuse for these failures. He’s been scoring 21.7 points per game with 5 assists per game too.

Rozier was picked 16th overall in the drafts, showing another high-potential player going to waste.

Nick Richards – Center

The losing streak continues with Richards. His last 5 games have also been major losses.

Mark Williams – Center

Williams is a rookie player but has been consistently brought onto the team mid-game. Williams played for around 17 minutes scoring an average of 7 points per game. That’s roughly 2 points every minute.

Williams is doing very well as a defensive player, as his blocks and steals have slowed down his opponents. The Hornets would do well to re-train Williams into a Guard.

Jalen McDaniels – Forward Center

McDaniels is a dramatic player for the Hornets but his 10.6 points per game haven’t been enough to pull Charlotte out of their losing streak.

Bryce McGowens – Guard

McGowens is a Rookie, but his time on the team has been monumental. Of his 5 latest games 2 of them were wins – a rare sight for this team. These wins correlate with the team’s trust in McGowen’s shots.

Against Huston, McGowen scored 10 points with a 75% Field Goal percentage, a 66.7% 3-Point percentage, and a 66.7% Free Throw percentage. He has similar stats against Atlanta, suggesting McGowens is wasted as a guard.

Dennis Smith Jr. – Guard

Smith is another guard with high field goal percentages, suggesting the Hornets are incorrectly prioritizing guards over forwards.

Theo Maledon – Guard

Maledon is another player who has seen a win in their last 5 games, this time against Oklahoma. Granted, Maledon didn’t add much to the game, but his 4 assists were greatly appreciated.

Cody Martin – Forward

Martin is one of the few real forwards on the Hornets. You might think the team is saving all of their good forwards and not sharing the spotlight, but like everyone else, Martin hasn’t seen many wins.

His average points per game is a measly 5, much worse than many of the guards.

Kelly Oubre Jr. – Forward Guard

Oubre is the exception to the rule. This forward is carrying the team with 20.2 points per game. Of his last 5 games, three of them were wins – that isn’t a coincidence. Injury has reduced his playtime, which in turn has reduced the Hornet’s changes in the season.

Gordon Hayward – Forward

Hayward has an average of 13.4 points per game, but even a claim like that hasn’t led to a recent win.

Also…

The other players on the team include JT Thor, Kai Jones, Mason Plumlee, and P.J. Washington. They are all forwards, but none have achieved more than 3 points per game.
